dnd.dashboard.title: Dungeons & Dragons
dnd.character-sheet.title: Character sheet
dnd.conditions.title: Conditions
dnd.conditions.blinded.title: Blinded
dnd.conditions.blinded.rule-1: A frightened creature has disadvantage on Ability Checks and Attack rolls while the source of its fear is within Line of Sight
dnd.conditions.blinded.rule-2: The creature can’t willingly move closer to the source of its fear
dnd.conditions.charmed.title: Charmed
dnd.conditions.charmed.rule-1: A charmed creature can’t Attack the charmer or target the charmer with harmful Abilities or magical Effects
dnd.conditions.charmed.rule-2: The charmer has advantage on any ability check to interact socially with the creature
dnd.conditions.deafened.title: Deafened
dnd.conditions.deafened.rule-1: A deafened creature can’t hear and automatically fails any ability check that requires hearing
dnd.conditions.frightened.title: Frightened
dnd.conditions.frightened.rule-1: A frightened creature has disadvantage on Ability Checks and Attack rolls while the source of its fear is within Line of Sight
dnd.conditions.frightened.rule-2: The creature can’t willingly move closer to the source of its fear
dnd.conditions.grappled.title: Grappled
dnd.conditions.grappled.rule-1: A grappled creature’s speed becomes 0, and it can’t benefit from any bonus to its speed
dnd.conditions.grappled.rule-2: The condition ends if the Grappler is incapacitated (see the condition)
dnd.conditions.grappled.rule-3: The condition also ends if an Effect removes the grappled creature from the reach of the Grappler or Grappling Effect, such as when a creature is hurled away by the Thunderwave spell
dnd.conditions.incapacitated.title: Incapacitated
dnd.conditions.incapacitated.rule-1: An incapacitated creature can’t take Actions or Reactions
dnd.conditions.invisible.title: Blinded
dnd.conditions.invisible.rule-1: An invisible creature is impossible to see without the aid of magic or a Special sense. For the Purpose of Hiding, the creature is heavily obscured. The creature’s Location can be detected by any noise it makes or any tracks it leaves
dnd.conditions.invisible.rule-2: Attack rolls against the creature have disadvantage, and the creature’s Attack rolls have advantage
dnd.conditions.paralyzed.title: Paralyzed
dnd.conditions.paralyzed.rule-1: A paralyzed creature is incapacitated (see the condition) and can’t move or speak
dnd.conditions.paralyzed.rule-2: The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity Saving Throws
dnd.conditions.paralyzed.rule-3: Attack rolls against the creature have advantage
dnd.conditions.paralyzed.rule-4: Any Attack that hits the creature is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature
dnd.conditions.petrified.title: Petrified
dnd.conditions.petrified.rule-1: A petrified creature is transformed, along with any nonmagical object it is wearing or carrying, into a solid inanimate substance (usually stone). Its weight increases by a factor of ten, and it ceases aging
dnd.conditions.petrified.rule-2: The creature is incapacitated (see the condition), can’t move or speak, and is unaware of its surroundings
dnd.conditions.petrified.rule-3: Attack rolls against the creature have advantage
dnd.conditions.petrified.rule-4: The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity Saving Throws
dnd.conditions.petrified.rule-5: The creature has Resistance to all damage
dnd.conditions.petrified.rule-6: The creature is immune to poison and disease, although a poison or disease already in its system is suspended, not neutralized
dnd.conditions.poisoned.title: Poisoned
dnd.conditions.poisoned.rule-1: A poisoned creature has disadvantage on Attack rolls and Ability Checks
dnd.conditions.prone.title: Prone
dnd.conditions.prone.rule-1: A prone creature’s only Movement option is to crawl, unless it stands up and thereby ends the condition
dnd.conditions.prone.rule-2: The creature has disadvantage on Attack rolls
dnd.conditions.prone.rule-3: An Attack roll against the creature has advantage if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature. Otherwise, the Attack roll has disadvantage
dnd.conditions.restrained.title: Restrained
dnd.conditions.restrained.rule-1: A restrained creature’s speed becomes 0, and it can’t benefit from any bonus to its speed
dnd.conditions.restrained.rule-2: Attack rolls against the creature have advantage, and the creature’s Attack rolls have disadvantage
dnd.conditions.restrained.rule-3: The creature has disadvantage on Dexterity Saving Throws
dnd.conditions.stunned.title: Stunned
dnd.conditions.stunned.rule-1: A stunned creature is incapacitated (see the condition), can’t move, and can speak only falteringly
dnd.conditions.stunned.rule-2: The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity Saving Throws
dnd.conditions.stunned.rule-3: Attack rolls against the creature have advantage
dnd.conditions.unconscious.title: Unconscious
dnd.conditions.unconscious.rule-1: An unconscious creature is incapacitated (see the condition), can’t move or speak, and is unaware of its surroundings
dnd.conditions.unconscious.rule-2: The creature drops whatever it’s holding and falls prone
dnd.conditions.unconscious.rule-3: The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity Saving Throws
dnd.conditions.unconscious.rule-4: Attack rolls against the creature have advantage
dnd.conditions.unconscious.rule-5: Any Attack that hits the creature is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature
dnd.conditions.exhaustion.title: Exhaustion
dnd.conditions.exhaustion.description-1: Some Special Abilities and environmental Hazards, such as starvation and the long-­term Effects of freezing or scorching temperatures, can lead to a Special condition called exhaustion. Exhaustion is measured in six levels. An Effect can give a creature one or more levels of exhaustion, as specified in the effect’s description.
dnd.conditions.exhaustion.description-2: If an already exhausted creature suffers another Effect that causes exhaustion, its current level of exhaustion increases by the amount specified in the effect’s description.
dnd.conditions.exhaustion.description-3: A creature suffers the Effect of its current level of exhaustion as well as all lower levels. For example, a creature suffering level 2 exhaustion has its speed halved and has disadvantage on Ability Checks.
dnd.conditions.exhaustion.description-4: An Effect that removes exhaustion reduces its level as specified in the effect’s description, with all exhaustion Effects Ending if a creature’s exhaustion level is reduced below 1.
dnd.conditions.exhaustion.description-5: Finishing a Long Rest reduces a creature’s exhaustion level by 1, provided that the creature has also ingested some food and drink.
dnd.conditions.exhaustion.levels:
Exhaustion Effects:
1: Disadvantage on Ability Checks
2: Speed halved
3: Disadvantage on Attack rolls and Saving Throws
4: Hit point maximum halved
5: Speed reduced to 0
6: Death
